newsitem.title: FRANCE: Algeria jails eight managers for graft.
newsitem.headline: Algeria jails eight managers for graft.

text.p: An Algerian court on Sunday sentenced eight managers in a state-owned enterprise to up to 15 years in jail for embezzling state assets, said the official Algerian news agency APS.
The eight from the food distribution Edipal firm were among a total of 47 people standing trial for their role in a 440 million dinars ($7.8 million) scandal.

The court in Djelfa, 230 km (130 miles) south of Algiers, condemned the eight to between three and 15 years' jail after they were convicted for "misappropriating state assets and signing deals without respect of the legislation", APS said.
The tribunal also sentenced an unspecified number of accused to seven years' imprisonment after the nine-day trial attended by 25 lawyers, it added.
The court condemned 22 people, who are at large, to death in absentia for the same charges.

The sentences were the harshest imposed since early in 1996 when Algerian authorities began issuing a stream of statements on arrests and jail sentences on senior officials in state-run business in a crackdown on graft.
The government vowed to wipe out corruption since President Liamine Zeroual put anti-graft high in his agenda in an attempt to bridge the gap of mistrust between ordinary Algerians and their leaders.
